title: hello world, throw us your questions here

replies.msg:
Ask us anything, although we are not native English speakers. We will try our best to provide an answer as the world should be aligned against any parties destroying freedom and democracy.

Throw us your questions with hashtags, so we know which topics you wanna know about.
I.e.

#hongkongprotest
What are your demands?

quote.msg: why hk people still protest after the bill was over

replies.msg:
We need universal suffrage for better long-term development but not CCP-controlled election.

And also to preserve the rule of law, by investigate police abusing protestors. There are reports (not yet proved though) protestors being tortured or even being killed (not yet confirmed) by the police...

Otherwise controversial bills and policies will come over and over again!
Welcome

Exactly what we are being fear of now.
What kind of citizens need to be afraid of their police force, who are supposed to protect their lives?

A foreigner asked me why the protesters would destroy the bakeries and Genki sushi restaurants a few days ago. However, I don’t know how to explain the purpose of our action to them because of my poor English. He shows support for the demonstration, but he told me that destroying the bakeries and sushi restaurant is wrong. Can someone explain the reasons here?
hello world

replies.msg:
Completely true.
1. HK government didn’t have prompt response to our demand.
2. Excessive unnecessary force and brutality from the police force are being used.
3. More and more accumulated and buried questions of the society are being exposed.
4. We are just fighting for what we are promised in the joint declaration between uk and Hk.

quote.msg: A foreigner asked me why the protesters would destroy the bakeries and Genki sushi restaurants a few days ago. However, I don’t know how to explain the purpose of our action to them because of my poor English. He shows support for the demonstration, but he told me that destroying the bakeries and sushi restaurant is wrong. Can someone explain the reasons here?

replies.msg:
Not a complete answer, but I will try my best to answer the question.
Genki Sushi and the bakeries are belonged to the Maxim's. Around two to four weeks ago, the daughter of the founder of the Maxim's had posted an announcement that she condemned what the protestors were doing and called them rioters. She even made false statements about the protestors which aimed to defame the protestors. Also, she said she would like to expel the students who participated in the strike that aimed to support the anti-extradition law bill movement.
Therefore, in response to her actions, we, the protestors had decided to 'decorate' or 'renovate' the Maxim's shops.

quote.msg: A friend of mine asking why HK people waving flags from the other counties

replies.msg: To ask for other countries' help. Hong Kong is a city with 7 millions people. We don't have the power to fight a totalitarian regime that ignores the freedom and right of Hong Kong people that are promised in the Basic Law. We need other countries that preserve the core value of freedom and human rights to help us to fight back.

replies.msg: The Chinese government basically assigns a Chief Executive to Hong Kong. And the CE was controlled by the Chinese government and started to apply what Chinese government is doing in Mainland China to Hong Kong. However, the Basic Law in Hong Kong promised us 'One Country, Two Systems' and this has obviously offended the principle. We want a CE that really care for HK people and really do what is the best for HK, for our home.

replies.msg:
I’m not very knowledgeable about this, but I’ll try to briefly explain the idea.
Since the handover of HK from UK to China. We don’t have the universal suffrage. The system of the chef executive election only allow candidates who are secretly handpicked by China to win. As a result, actions taken by this CE is actually controlled by China.
As you may know, the protest in HK actually uncovered lots and lots of serious issues, ie one country two system is long gone, the CE has to take order from China. Therefore, we need a CE who wholeheartedly takes care of HK, but not pleasing his/her boss, China.

quote.msg: why hk people still protest after the bill was over

replies.msg:
It simply came too little and too late.
After two peaceful massive marches and three months of continuous unrest, Carrie announced the withdrawal of the hated extradition bill.

BUT, the police brutality, selective enforcement and the neglect of government boiled the public sentiment to a point where the announcement satisfied nobody.

Five demands were raised at an early stage where most ppl accept, including pro-Beijing citizens. (Setting up independent inquiry and universal suffrage are commonly agreed.) Satisfying only one of the demands hence satisfy nobody.

Regarding police brutality and selective enforcement, there are countless examples but 721, 831 and San Uk Ling are critical dates/place. Look it up and ask further if anyone is interested.

When Carrie realizes announcing the withdrawal of extradition bill after three months, and setting up useless ‘dialogues’ aren’t working.....from her trip to Beijing on 1st Oct, she announced anti-mask law in hope of easing violence. However, it came from <emergency regulations ordinance>, a colonial law that hasn’t been used in ages. The ordinance grants the chief executive, aka curry lamb, supreme power. Skipping legislation, she can ban the internet, introduce curfew, confiscate private property, extend detention hours........doing the complete opposite of what Carrie wished, the law backfired with huge crowds appearing on streets again.......

This thread is for anyone interested in ‘why protestors damaged certain companies like Maxim?’

The world should be aware of CCP, it is the one and only political party in China and they are trying to limit the freedom of expression not only in China but everywhere. Human rights are not guaranteed under the power of the CCP. I counldnt imagine a political power like this is rapidly expanding to everywhere in the world thru their plots: the belt and road initiative, trades, business opportunities, investments, pro-China immigrants, etc. They are trying to grab you and when you get used to them, they will suck your blood dry.

It doesn't matter if you are Hong Konger or not, we all should work together to take down the CCP, especially for those from mainland China, stand up and fight for your rights! The political party does not necessarily represent China, people do. It could be tough, in life what you really want will never come easy isnt it? Act now before its too late.

Five demands, not one less.
Fight for freedom, stand with Hong Kong

quote.msg: A friend of mine asking why HK people waving flags from the other counties

replies.msg:
To catch international attention and celebrate universal values the countries believe in

US flags appeared frequently for <HK humans rights and democracy act>. It will hopefully impose sanctions on officials that stripped the freedom and such from HKers.

UK flags appeared frequently as well for our historical ties. <Sino-British joint declaration> is said to be void and UK hence is responsible to intervene.

Overall I personally think flags waving are the cries of HKers to the free world....

quote.msg: what is Mentally-disabled Blue?

So we call them mentally-disabled, they lose the ability of independent thinking.

replies.msg:
okay, I will try to explain this with my limited English.

MTR is always the pride of Hong Kong people and it sets a role model for the world's mass transit system.
Even in the gangsters raiding in July, MTR did what they were supposed to do: arrange an empty train for the affected citizens evacuating the scene.

Turning point
Everything was fine until August, MTR was accused by "Global Times" (mouthpiece of China) that they were not cooperating with the Police Force and helped the protesters to get away after peaceful protests. Moreover, MTR was also categorized "helps to sabotage law and orders", same as Cathay Pacific.
Since then, MTR used excuses (for the safety of staff and public) to hindered citizens' transportation to attend public activities, even before any conflicts occurred. They were just helping the government to reduce the number of HK people going on the street and express their demands.
Most importantly, 31 Aug, the darkest day of MTR history. The Police Force stormed into a train and attack passengers indifferently. They didn't care whether they are normal citizens or protestors at all. After the incidents, people were injured severely and people were disappeared. HongKongers then urged MTR to publish their CCTV record in order to make all the rumors clear. They refused to do so and claimed some of the CCTVs were damaged by protestors.
We actually just had a holiday without services provided by MTR too, they claimed that stations were damaged by protestors and they had repair to do.
HongKongers are sick of all these excuses, what kind of public transport just help the government (which suppresses their citizens' freedom) and refuse to provide the truth to the public?

(my english is not good enough, bros and sis, feel free to supplement if i have missed anything)
